document.docAuthor: Fryxell, Paul A. & Harriman, Neil A.
document.docTitle: The nomenclatural history of Cienfuegosia tuberculata (Malvaceae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The nomenclatural history of Cienfuegosia tuberculata (Malvaceae)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Rancho Santa Ana Botanic Garden, 1500 N. College Ave., Claremont, CA 91711, U.S.A.; e-mail: pfryxell@mail.utexas.edu Biology Department, University of Wisconsin Oshkosh, 800 Algoma Blvd., Oshkosh, WI 54901 U.S.A.; e-mail: harriman@uwosh.edu

emphasis.docTitle:
The nomenclatural history of
Cienfuegosia tuberculata (Malvaceae)

subSection.paragraph: PAUL A. FRYXELL 1 & NEIL A. HARRIMAN 2

paragraph.emphasis: 1 Rancho Santa Ana Botanic Garden, 1500 N. College Ave., Claremont, CA 91711, U.S.A. ; e-mail: pfryxell@mail.utexas.edu 2 Biology Department, University of Wisconsin Oshkosh, 800 Algoma Blvd., Oshkosh, WI 54901 U.S.A. ; e-mail: harriman@uwosh.edu

subSection.paragraph:
The names
Cienfuegosia digitata
and
Cienfuegosia tuberculata
were published simultaneously by Cavanilles as alternate names for the same species. In another publication ( Anonymous 1787 )
Cienfuegosia tuberculata
was used for this species, but the alternative name,
C. digitata
, was not mentioned. The name
C. tuberculata
has not otherwise appeared or been accounted for in any subsequent literature until now. It is here formally stated to be a synonym of
Cienfuegosia digitata .

Antonio Jos√© Cavanilles published a well-known series entitled Monadelphiae classis dissertationes decem over the years 1785 to 1790. In the second of these ten dissertations Cavanilles (1786) published a description of the genus
Cienfuegosia Cavanilles
on an unnumbered page immediately preceding the plates in the back of the volume. In the third of these ten dissertations Cavanilles (1787) described and illustrated the single species that he included in his new genus. Here the genus is described on page 174 and the species,
Cienfuegosia digitata Cavanilles
, on pages 174‚Äì175. This description refers to plate 72, figure 2. The plate itself occupies a full (unnumbered) page, and the caption for this plate is found separately on page 185. Both the caption and the plate itself bear the name
Cienfuegosia tuberculata
for figure 2, rather than
C. digitata
as given on page 174. Moreover, the
Index
(p. 116) refers to this species (species number 259) as
Cienfuegosia tuberculata
. Thus, Cavanilles validly published two alternative names for a single species and provided no indication of preference of one or the other name. In subsequent literature, with one exception, this species is known as
C. digitata
, and the name
C. tuberculata
is nowhere acknowledged to exist, so far as we have been able to ascertain.

However, we have recently discovered a previously overlooked publication ( Anonymous 1787 ), in which the first three dissertations of Cavanilles are reviewed and announced, with special attention to the ten new genera that Cavanilles had proposed therein, including
Cienfuegosia
. This publication has not been wholly overlooked, because it is cited in Stafleu & Mennega (1995: 468 , #25122), but it has been overlooked nomenclaturally as a place in which the name
C. tuberculata
was accepted. In referring to
Cienfuegosia
and its single species, the anonymous author described them very fully and cited the illustration of Cavanilles. He used the name
Cienfuegosia tuberculata
instead of
C. digitata
, and did not mention
C. digitata
either as an alternative name or as a synonym. He paraphrased the generic description and translated it from Latin into French, but quoted the specific description verbatim in Latin.

Both publications can be dated as appearing in February 1787 , explicitly so stated in Anonymous (1787) , and inferred in the analysis given in Stafleu & Cowan (1976) for Cavanilles‚Äô Tertia Dissertatio . On the basis of internal evidence, the Anonymous paper appeared after the Tertia Dissertatio was available. Thus we may conclude that Cavanilles published the name
C. tuberculata
prior to the publication of the name by the anonymous author, and that the authorship is to be attributed solely to Cavanilles.

The following dates may be noted in the Tertia Dissertatio . The title page bears the date ‚ÄúM.DCC.LXXXVII‚Äù (= 1787). The Praefatio (on p. 115) is dated 29 November 1786 . At the end (on pages that are unnumbered but which occupy the two pages that follow page 186) is the ‚ÄúExtrait des Registres de l‚ÄôAcad√©mie Royale des Sciences, du 23 D√©cembre 1786 ‚Äù with signatures of ‚Äú A. L. de Jussieu, Fougeroux de Bondaroy , et de Lamarck ,‚Äù and with the following statement and signature, ‚ÄúJe certifie la present Extrait conform√© √† son original et au jugement de l‚ÄôAcad√©mie. [signed] le Marquis de Condorcet ,‚Äù also dated 23 December 1786 .

It seems clear that the content of the Tertia Dissertatio was generally available to at least a part of the botanical community of Paris prior to February 1787 , which enabled the anonymous author to prepare his extract so promptly.

A perusal of various general botanical compilations, such as Willdenow (1800: 723), Persoon (1807: 240) , Lamarck & Poiret (1811: 260) , De Candolle (1824: 457) , Sprengel (1826: 64), Don (1831: 488) , Steudel (1840: 649, vol. 1), Walpers (1845: 92), Dietrich (1847: 785) , Pfeiffer (1871: 754), and Kuntze (1891: 69) , does not give any indication that the name
Cienfuegosia tuberculata
was known to the larger botanical community. (The search was made under the generic name
Cienfuegosia
and any of its variants or synonyms, including
Cienfugosia
,
Cienfuegia
,
Fugosia
,
Redutea ,
etc.). The detailed study of the Cavanilles herbarium by Garilleti (1993) , including quotations from annotation labels on herbarium specimens, does not include any reference to the name
C. tuberculata
. The literature on the genus
Cienfuegosia
(e.g., Garcke 1860 , Ulbrich 1914, Rodrigo 1941 , Hutchinson 1947 , Fryxell 1969 , Blanchard 1978 , Krapovickas 2003 ) has also failed to turn up any reference to this name. Finally, insofar as we are aware, the various African floras that cover the areas where
Cienfuegosia digitata
is native, such as Masters (1868: 209) , Hutchinson & Dalziel (1927: 265), Phillips (1951: 501) , Andrews, (1952: 17), Exell (1961: 426) , Berhaut (1971: 153), Boudet & Lebrun (1986: 94) , and Barry & Celles, (1991: 267), all refer to this plant by either
Cienfuegosia digitata ,
Cienfuegia digitata (Cavanilles) Willdenow
, or
Fugosia digitata (Cavanilles) Persoon
, and not by the name
Cienfuegosia tuberculata
.

In the original description of the species, both
Cienfuegosia digitata
and
C. tuberculata
are explicitly associated with the same illustration. Thus Cavanilles published two alternative names for a single species (cf.
McNeill et al. 2006
: Art. 34.2), but neither he nor any subsequent author, insofar as we can discover, has ever chosen one name over the other. Common usage is that the species is widely known as
Cienfuegosia digitata
(or sometimes as
Fugosia digitata
or
Cienfuegia digitata
), and the name
Cienfuegosia tuberculata
is absent from this literature. Therefore, in the interest of nomenclatural stability and according to Art. 11.5 (
McNeill et al. 2006
), we formally state the following synonymy:

Preferred name:
Cienfuegosia digitata Cavanilles, Diss .
3: 174. t. 72. f. 2 (1787).
Type : SENEGAL
,

Adanson 145A ( lectotype : P-389375; possible isolectotype: MA-475523 (see Garilleti 1993: 143 ). Synonym:
Cienfuegosia tuberculata Cavanilles, Diss .
3: 185. t. 72. f. 2 (1787).

An additional (but incidental) reason for making this choice is that the epithet ‚Äúdigitata‚Äù is clearly descriptive of the form of the leaves, whereas the epithet ‚Äútuberculata‚Äù does not describe any feature of the plant that we can discern.

A secondary purpose of the present article dealing with the history of the name
Cienfuegosia tuberculata Cavanilles
is to make it more widely known, lest some future botanist republish the name for a newly discovered representative of this genus, thereby producing a later homonym. This effort is in the spirit of ‚Äúpreventing later homonyms‚Äù ( Mabberley 1983 ). Discoveries of new species of
Cienfuegosia
continue to be made (e.g. Fryxell 1967 , 1969 , Krapovickas 2003 ), and further such discoveries, requiring naming, are to be anticipated.
We are grateful to Gerrit Davidse, Kanchi Gandhi, and an anonymous reviewer for helpful comments.
